items.title: _repr_html_ not shown on RTD
items.body:
I am a bit puzzled on this, and wondered if anyone has come across the same.

So locally, sphinx-gallery captures my `empymod.Report()`, which is a `_repr_html_`-method:
![Selection_001](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8020943/90668216-035e6380-e250-11ea-8f8e-e5dd345eb5d3.png)

but on readthedocs, it doesn't:
![Selection_002](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8020943/90668230-08bbae00-e250-11ea-8f98-ad5ed9e4f1d0.png)

Has anyone come across that issue?
The `sphinx=3.2.1` and `sphinx-gallery=0.7.0` versions are the same.

Has anyone come across this?

(The full RTD-build is here: https://readthedocs.org/projects/empymod/builds/11697232/)


(I have not (yet) tested, if this only happens with the last cell or not.)

items.title: Reference :ref:`sphx_glr_auto_examples` goes to SciKit-Learn examples
items.body:
We are using `sphinx-gallery` to generate samples for our package. However, I've noticed that in our ReST files, attempts to link to the examples using:
```
:ref:`sphx_glr_auto_examples`
```
result in links to the SciKit-Learn examples. This is undoubtedly due to the inclusion of sklearn in our `intersphinx_mapping` ... but we would like to be able to send readers to our own examples. Is there some way we can override the reference name for ours?

Our docs are built using `sphinx-gallery` 0.7.0, on Linux.

items.title: Pass command line arguments to examples
items.body:
I have a bunch of examples included in my sphinx-gallery and these examples accept comand-line arguments.
Is it possible to pass command-line arguments through sphinx-gallery? I couldn't find that option in the documentation.

Two use cases would be (in my case):
- control the duration of the execution of examples: It would be nice to control how long the examples take via a command-line arguments (e.g. controlling the number of iterations in some optimization scheme), such that I can build my docs with full functionality in continuous integration, but I'm able to control the runtime so that CI doesn't take too long.
- control the creation of figures. In one example, I am using OpenAI gym, and this causes a problem when I render their environment (rendered with `pyglet`). I receive an error when I execute the example via sphinx-gallery, which is caused by some problem in `pyglet` (as far as I understand). It would be nice to be able to switch off the rendering via the command line.

items.title: How to scrape for images without executing example scripts
items.body:
Hi, 
I am trying to create a gallery of my examples *without* executing the scripts but *with* images. The use case is that I have already executed the scripts before building the documentation and the images were saved to disk. Now I want to build the documentation and scrape the folder for images (png files) to add them to the gallery in the documentation.

As far as I understood, this example is supposed to deal with this case: https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/advanced.html#example-2-detecting-image-files-on-disk
(at least that's how I interpret its documentation).

However, when I include this in my `conf.py`, the scraper is only executed for scripts that are run during `make html`, i.e., during building the docs.

For instance, if my files are not covered by the `filename_pattern` in the `sphinx_gallery_conf`, i.e., not executed, the scraper is not run. 
The same happens if I include them in the pattern, but set `plot_gallery: False`.

What am I doing wrong here?
Thanks, and apologies if this has been asked before, I couldn't find any precedent.

items.title: Thumbnail oversampling
items.body:
https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/blob/353ff9f972c240e3855e91283a89dddef669adf9/sphinx_gallery/gen_gallery.py#L64

What is the reason for 2.5x oversampling? We had a recent PR for reducing that for Matplotlib specifically (https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/17275). We were assuming that 2x is enough, and one may even get sharper pictures on non-scaled screens.

items.title: Gallery example using plotly
items.body:
Hi, I was planning to submit a PR showing how to use plotly figures in sphinx-gallery examples and I'm opening this issue to prepare this PR and to be sure whether it would be well received.

There are two ways to use plotly in sphinx-gallery:
- either by using the recently introduced `_repr_html_` of plotly figure objects. This is the easiest way to use plotly figures, but then you don't get png files saved for the thumbnails
- or use a custom scraper provided by the plotly package, which saves both png and html files. For this scraper to work you need to install the `orca` package which is easy to install with conda but with pip you need to install other dependencies (basically because you need a browser to run to save a figure as png). We're planning to make this process easier (ie pip-installable) in the coming months.

My plan was to write an example for the sphinx-gallery website using just `_repr_html_` since it's easy to do, and to mention that the scraper exists if you want to get the png thumbnails as well. How does that sound? Also where should I put the example?  In the main gallery or create a separate gallery like the mayavi one?

items.title: Working with pre-built galleries
items.body:
I'm using `sphinx-gallery` to build example galleries. The documentation is hosted on [Read the Docs (RTD)](https://pystiche.readthedocs.io/en/latest/galleries/examples/index.html). My examples rely on a GPU, so I can't let them be built by RTD.

I came up with the following to overcome this: I've set up a separate build server that spins up every few hours and runs a `sphinx-gallery` build for the current `master`. Afterwards the generated galleries are uploaded. Within the `conf.py` I detect if a build is performed by RTD and download the pre-built galleries instead. 

I've ran into the following problems:

1. I need to set `plot_gallery=False` since the pre-built galleries might not match the examples in the current commit. If I don't RTD tries to rebuild the changed examples, which will fail. Still, sometimes it recompiles the galleries without running them. I've yet to figure out how to reproduce this. I think it detects non-matching checksums, but I'm not sure yet. Unfortunately this removes the output from the pre-built galleries, defeating their purpose.
2. In response to 1. I've tried to remove the `"sphinx_gallery.gen_gallery"` from the `extensions` if run by RTD with moderate success. The output is preserved, but I think some "style files" (not sure if this is the correct term) are missing. For example the background color of the output blocks is no longer yellow, the thumbnails in the gallery are no longer clickable, and so on.

Is there any way to overcome these issues? Can I for example force `sphinx-gallery` to accept the pre-built galleries or copy the "style files" without executing the scripts?

items.title: DOC Builder types clarification
items.body:
Our doc intro says:

> Sphinx-Gallery is a Sphinx extension that builds an HTML gallery of examples from any set of Python scripts.

items.title: Provide a Sphinx directive to insert a mini-gallery
items.body:
In SunPy, we've started using [mini-galleries](https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/configuration.html#add-mini-galleries-for-api-documentation), but I found the procedure for insertion to be a little clunky, and the mini-gallery to be a little limiting.  I wrote [a Sphinx directive for SunPy](https://github.com/ayshih/sunpy/blob/c7f8cb2776acb21a9029e943c868503772740b2b/docs/conf.py#L320), with the following advantages:

- No need to specify the backreferences directory or the `.examples` suffix
- No potential omission of the `<div class="sphx-glr-clear">` HTML block
- Removes the heading from the backreferences file (in case it doesn't match the desired heading level)
- If multiple inputs are provided (separated by spaces), the output mini-gallery concatenates all of the relevant examples

Live example ([found here](https://docs.sunpy.org/en/latest/code_ref/coordinates/rotatedsunframe.html#example-uses-of-rotatedsunframe)):
```rst
.. minigallery:: sunpy.coordinates.RotatedSunFrame
```

Combining multiple (possibly unrelated) objects into single mini-gallery:
```rst
.. minigallery:: sunpy.coordinates.sun.earth_distance sunpy.coordinates.transform_with_sun_center
```

Useful for when the same object can be accessed from multiple namespaces:
```rst
.. minigallery:: sunpy.coordinates.RotatedSunFrame sunpy.coordinates.metaframes.RotatedSunFrame
```

Would `sphinx-gallery` be interested in including such a directive (i.e, upstreamed from SunPy)?  It would need to be modified to be a bit more general and robust, of course.  Looking at some open issues, it looks like there may be interest (#38, #413), but also possibly a rule to not provide directives in this project?

items.title: Output of logger is not captured if the logger is created in a different cell
items.body:
Logger output is not captured if the logger is not created within the same cell. Consider the following example:

```python
"""
Logging test
============
"""

###############################################################################

import logging
import sys


def create_logger(name=None):
    logger = logging.getLogger(name=name)
    logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

    sh = logging.StreamHandler(sys.stdout)
    sh.setLevel(logging.INFO)
    logger.addHandler(sh)

    return logger


###############################################################################

logger = create_logger("first_logger")
logger.info("I'm in the same cell that I was created in.")


###############################################################################

logger.info("I'm **not** in the same cell that I was created in.")

###############################################################################

logger = create_logger("second_logger")
logger.info("I'm again in the same cell that I was created in.")
```

Running `make html` generates the following extract in the corresponding`.rst` file

```rst
.. code-block:: default
   :lineno-start: 26


    logger = create_logger("first_logger")
    logger.info("I'm in the same cell that I was created in.")

.. rst-class:: sphx-glr-script-out

 Out:

 .. code-block:: none

    I'm in the same cell that I was created in.

.. code-block:: default
   :lineno-start: 32


    logger.info("I'm **not** in the same cell that I was created in.")

.. code-block:: default
   :lineno-start: 36


    logger = create_logger("second_logger")
    logger.info("I'm again in the same cell that I was created in.")

.. rst-class:: sphx-glr-script-out

 Out:

 .. code-block:: none

    I'm again in the same cell that I was created in.
```
(Whitespace removed to enhance readability).

As you can see, the second info is missing. If I run this file manually with python all three lines are printed on `stdout`.

items.title: Inconsistency with applying & removing sphinx gallery configs
items.body:
In trying to add the `remove_config_comments` option (from #487), we noticed an inconsistency in where configs can be put vs. where they get removed from. 

Specifically, configs, (at least `# sphinx_gallery_thumbnail_number = X`) can be put in a text block, and have effect. But the `remove_config_comments` only removes these lines from code blocks. 

So, for example this setup has effect, but the line doesn't get removed from the render:
```
######################################
# Words, words, words.
#
# sphinx_gallery_thumbnail_number = X
#
```

Perhaps these configs weren't really intended to be placed in text blocks? But it does work, and we had them in text blocks. It then took us a while to figure out why the `remove_config_comments` didn't seem to work. 

Options for updating:
- Since config lines currently can be placed in text blocks, and have effect, maybe the  `remove_config_comments` option should drop them from there too?
- If the current behavior can't easily be changed, perhaps a quick note in the documentation about the  `remove_config_comments` option could specify that this only has effect for configs in code blocks.

items.title: thumbnails cause heavy gallery pages and long loading time
items.body:
I would like to start a discussion regarding the loading time of galleries.

I opened here a [PR for scikit-image](https://github.com/scikit-image/scikit-image/pull/4613) showing that thumbnails are responsible for long loading time and large bandwidth consumption. Comments show that scikit-learn and matplotlib are also affected by this issue.

I made some tests and the mitigation I found on the user side is to reduce slightly the default resolution of the thumbnails. As our galleries are expected to grow, I think that a longer term solution would be appreciated.

I read the sphinx-gallery code and saw that you are using your own thumbnail generator, relaying on pillow. So far, thumbnails are saved in png (because our plots with matplotlib are so), which is particularly good for rendering edges and fonts. The drawback is the file size as explained above. I made some tests with pillow and I couldn't reach better performances while keeping a png format.

Have you ever considered to switch to jpg? Jpg has some advantages such as a good compression level (with loss) and also [progressive loading](https://www.infoq.com/news/2019/09/lazy-loading-http-range-requests/). I would like also to know whether svg could provide better performances for plots. 

I'm not a master in web optimization, so I'm open to other opinions.
Thank you!

CC @tacaswell @emmanuelle

items.title: Sphinx-Gallery Binder links: environment.yml does not get "installed"
items.body:
In our mne-bids package we want to generate binder links for each sphinx gallery example, according to the [sphinx gallery binder docs](https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/configuration.html#binder-links).

We followed the docs closely, everything builds without issues, and at a first glance everything seems to work.

**The issue**: the `environment.yml` file that we supply does not seem to get installed ... all packages we think should be there are giving import errors.

Here is the binder spec ([link to conf.py](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-bids/blob/6a5fff726f52b36e3cb86b6c35a3601b9aa5e146/doc/conf.py#L139-L148)):

```Python

# filepath_prefix='v0.3'
    'binder': {
        # Required keys
        'org': 'mne-tools',
        'repo': 'mne-bids',
        'branch': 'gh-pages',  # noqa: E501 Can be any branch, tag, or commit hash. Use a branch that hosts your docs.
        'binderhub_url': 'https://mybinder.org',  # noqa: E501 Any URL of a binderhub deployment. Must be full URL (e.g. https://mybinder.org).
        'filepath_prefix': filepath_prefix,  # noqa: E501 A prefix to prepend to any filepaths in Binder links.
        'dependencies': [
            './environment.yml',
        ],
```

The html build of our docs is then pushed to a subdirectory on the `gh-pages` branch, see [GitHub view here](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-bids/tree/gh-pages/v0.3).

As expected, our `environment.yml` got copied to a [binder](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-bids/blob/gh-pages/v0.3/binder/environment.yml) directory and our notebooks have been nicely built and are in [`/notebooks/auto_examples`](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-bids/tree/gh-pages/v0.3/notebooks/auto_examples).

For each notebook a link has been inserted, such as this one (which seems correct):

[`https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/mne-tools/mne-bids/gh-pages?filepath=v0.3/notebooks/auto_examples/rename_brainvision_files.ipynb`](https://mybinder.org/v2/gh/mne-tools/mne-bids/gh-pages?filepath=v0.3/notebooks/auto_examples/rename_brainvision_files.ipynb)

clicking on the link opens binder ... everything is fine --> until we try to import things like "matplotlib", which is defined in our supplied [environment.yml](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-bids/blob/a54f028cde14e2016621a971666de46e688d449a/v0.3/binder/environment.yml#L12) and which thus SHOULD have been installed for binder.

buuut :disappointed:  it's not installed.

Is Binder somehow not finding the `binder/environment.yml` file and thus assuming there is nothing to install?

What's the issue here? How can I solve it?

Feel free to browse our [stable docs](https://mne.tools/mne-bids/stable/auto_examples/rename_brainvision_files.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-rename-brainvision-files-py) if that helps you find the issue.

items.title: thumbnails from loaded figures
items.body:
I have a couple of examples where I compare one code to other, similar codes. These examples produce all very similar figures. I would therefore prefer the thumbs to be more informative, e.g. the logo of the code I am comparing to.

In other cases each example presents a method. Again, the plot itself is not very informative, but a little figure/sketch/drawing of the method would be great.

Is there any way how one can specify a, per-example-basis, figure for the thumbnail?

Or do you think it would be possible to extend the following directive
```# sphinx_gallery_thumbnail_number = 2```
 to also accept strings? E.g.,
```# sphinx_gallery_thumbnail_number = 'path/to/figure.png'```

These are some related issues/PRs I found, but none of them resolves it. #5 actually already suggested similar things, but it was closed then referring to the then introduced scraper API. However, I don't think the scraper API addresses this particular use-case.

items.title: `make html-noplot` instructions outdated
items.body:
I think the instructions
```
html-noplot:
    $(SPHINXBUILD) -D plot_gallery=0 -b html $(ALLSPHINXOPTS) $(BUILDDIR)/html
    @echo
    @echo "Build finished. The HTML pages are in $(BUILDDIR)/html."
```
given on https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/configuration.html#without-execution are outdated for the newer versions of sphinx which have a catch-all target.

In my case it resulted in 
```
docs/> make html-noplot
sphinx-build -D plot_gallery=0 -b html  _build/html
usage: sphinx-build [OPTIONS] SOURCEDIR OUTPUTDIR [FILENAMES...]
sphinx-build: error: the following arguments are required: outputdir, filenames
Makefile:15: recipe for target 'html-noplot' failed
make: *** [html-noplot] Error 2
```

The following would work (an adaption of the catch-all line):
```
html-noplot:
	@$(SPHINXBUILD) -M html "$(SOURCEDIR)" "$(BUILDDIR)" -D plot_gallery=0 $(SPHINXOPTS) $(O)
```
but I don't know if there is a better/preferred way for this.

items.title: last_notebook_cell
items.body:
Could a `last_notebook_cell` option be added much like the `first_notebook_cell` option for adding snippets that we want executed at the end of the downloaded notebook? This would be used to perhaps report on the user's environment with a tool like [`scooby`](https://github.com/banesullivan/scooby):

```py
sphinx_gallery_conf = {
    ...
    'last_notebook_cell': ("# Report on the environment specs\n"
                            "import scooby\n",
                            "scooby.Report()",)
}
```

With something like this, a user could download the example, run it, and encounter an error then immediately share the environment report... I imagine this will be useful for PyVista (`pv.Report`) and `mne-python` (`mne.sys_info()`)

items.body:

items.title: MAINT: Better error messages
items.body: As [pointed out](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/599/files#r369287580) by @mgeier, raising plain Python errors is not as nice as raising Sphinx-specific variants. We should update our internal exceptions.

items.title: Reduce the amount of hard dependencies?
items.body:
In `setup.py`, there seem to be a lot of requirements in `install_requires` (which is populated from `requirements.txt`).

* [x] `setuptools` seems to be a strange requirement, since `setup.py` already imports it (before reading the list of requirements).

* [x] `matplotlib` is of course an important use case for SG, but is it really required? AFAICT, it's not used in the code, only in tests. There are use cases for SG without Matplotlib, right?

* [x] `pillow` seems to be needed for `scale_image()`. But what if no scaling is needed (for example when using only SVG images)?
   Also, why is this a hard requirement but in the code it looks like a soft requirement:

   https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/blob/dff998dc51eb1c718be900e12aaa6394f61e5218/sphinx_gallery/utils.py#L23-L27

* [x] `sphinx>=1.8.3` I guess is justified because of the specific version. But I'm not quite sure.

* [x] `seaborn` is only included on `READTHEDOCS`, but it still seems strange. It would probably be better to use a `.readthedocs.yml` with probably a few "extra" requirements. Or probably a separate `requirements.txt` only for the docs?

items.title: instances not getting correct CSS classes
items.body: I would like to use CSS selectors to style instances of a class differently from the class constructor. For example, in the first code block of [this section of an MNE-Python tutorial](https://mne.tools/stable/auto_tutorials/intro/plot_10_overview.html#preprocessing) we get variable name `ica` and class constructor `mne.preprocessing.ICA` having exactly the same CSS classes on their `a` tags, and the nested `span` tags are also the same (`class='n'`).  According to the discussion over there (specifically [this comment](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-python/pull/7181#issuecomment-571683218) and [this reply](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-python/pull/7181#issuecomment-571685516)) the instance should have additional classes (`sphx-glr-backref-instance` and `sphx-glr-backref-type-class`) that the constructor doesn't get.

items.title: BUG: Bugs with backref links
items.body:
Here are bugs I've seen with the backref links:

- [x] Class instances after creation sometimes [only get](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-python/pull/7181#issuecomment-571685516) the `sphx-glr-backref-module-mne` class, not `sphx-glr-backref-type-class` and `sphx-glr-backref-instance` -- see also #588 (addressed in #591)
- [x] `np.random.RandomState` does not link properly (#593)
- [x] Method parsing is incomplete, in MNE things like `ica.plot_properties` do not link even though they should. This could be because of greedy replacement of `ica` occurring before `ica.plot_properties` can be replaced, or could be a problem with `get_mapping` (or downstream of there) (#596).
- [x] There are [extra / incorrect backrefs](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/584#issuecomment-571601897)

Hopefully to be fixed by follow-up PRs.

items.title: BUG backreferences not working for functions if not imported directly
items.body:
Creation of [mini-galleries](https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/configuration.html#add-mini-galleries-for-api-documentation) with `backreferences_dir` and `doc_module` generates an empty rst file if you use a function in an example like this:

```
import package.module

package.module.my_fun()
```

It works if you directly import the function in the example:

```
from package.module import my_fun

my_fun()
```

or if you import the function in the `__init__.py` file of the package (i.e.:

```
from .module import (
    my_fun,
    )
```

Note that this is only for functions. Classes work fine in all cases.

Refer to https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sample-project/pull/1#issuecomment-566664628 for suggestion on how to fix.

items.title: greedy backreferences
items.body:
I'm puzzled by two points related to backreferences, which have been introduced by version 0.5 of sphinx-gallery:
- it seems that intersphinx links are generated not only for functions or class constructors, but also for instances of objects of modules selected for backreferences. For example in https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/auto_examples/plot_3_capture_repr.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-plot-3-capture-repr-py integer variables have links to the Python doc, or in https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/stable/auto_examples/plot_0_sin.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-plot-0-sin-py numpy arrays also have links. Is this done on purpose? With this behaviour example pages become very busy with links (see for example https://scikit-image.org/docs/dev/auto_examples/color_exposure/plot_rgb_to_hsv.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-color-exposure-plot-rgb-to-hsv-py)
- modules listed in the `intersphinx_mapping` variable of `conf.py` seem to generate backreferences even if they are not listed in SG's `reference_url` dict. This was not the case with version 0.4.

I tried to track down when the change appeared, maybe it's https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/commit/3acd37b716bc5684da0f4f4d7054e2ca0f3d66d8#diff-33215ef937b7c3d86fe0a23425c585e4 but I'm not sure. Happy to dig more if needed but I'd like to know first whether this is a desired behaviour or not.

items.title: typing.TYPE_CHECKING is True at runtime in executed .py files
items.body:
First, thanks for the great package. I'm already finding it very useful.

When trying to import a package in one of my .py files which I'm including in the gallery, it was hitting circular imports which are not there when importing the package normally. I tracked it down to the use of:

```
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING
if TYPE_CHECKING:
    import my_module
```

I found that when my .py file for the gallery is importing the package, it is executing `import my_module` which should not happen at runtime. 

I then confirmed the behavior by modifying my .py for the gallery to have:
```
import typing
typing.TYPE_CHECKING
```

as the first cell, and it indeed shows `True` in the output. I was able to make my example run by adding:

```
import typing
typing.TYPE_CHECKING=False
```

as the first cell. Then the import of the package works normally. But I would prefer to not have this at the beginning of all my gallery .py files.

Any idea why `typing.TYPE_CHECKING` is being set to `True` while executing .py gallery files?

items.title: How best to handle data files?
items.body:
In NetworkX, several of our examples read data files, which are stored in the same directory as the corresponding example script:
- https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/drawing/plot_knuth_miles.py
- https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/drawing/plot_sampson.py
- https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/drawing/plot_lanl_routes.py
- https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/graph/plot_roget.py
- https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/graph/plot_words.py

For `plot_knuth_miles.py`, you can see that we added the following to the docstring:
``` 
The data file can be found at:
https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/examples/drawing/knuth_miles.txt.gz
```

But as you can see in issue https://github.com/networkx/networkx/issues/3692, we didn't add it to `plot_sampson.py`.
I can easily add links to all the example scripts that need it, but I was wondering if there is a better solution that would be helpful to other projects.

More specifically:
1. Is adding a link in the docstring the best solution?
2. Should the examples require internet access?  If so, should we grab data files from the network in our script?
3. Should something be added to the sphinx-gallery documentation suggesting "best practice"?
4. Should sphinx-gallery auto-create download links in the gallery?
5. @choldgraf also brought up how to best handle this for Binder links for gallery notebooks.

items.title: Making sphinx-gallery parallel_write_safe
items.body: At the moment, sphinx-gallery is marked as not being ``parallel_write_safe`` (it is explicitly set to ``False``), but it's not clear what the blocker is there. Is this something that is potentially fixable, or are there fundamental limitations in how sphinx-gallery works? (at the moment sphinx-gallery is the only extension that is stopping docs in several packages I work on to be built in parallel in the write step).

items.title: Documentation is ahead of current release
items.body:
Currently documentation is built from master, meaning that the documentation is updated for new features not available in the current release. This can cause confusion ([esp for big changes](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/541#issuecomment-552217045)).

Maybe we can update documentation with releases (like some other projects)?

items.title: Last word in rst used as code
items.body:
If an example `.py` file ends with an rst block, Sphinx-Gallery thinks the last word of the rst block is code and tries to execute it, unless there is an empty line after the rst block.

For example:

```Python
"""
Test
####

test
"""

print('hello')

#%%
# This is a sentence.
```

Gives: 
![Screenshot_2019-10-09 Test — mwe 0 documentation](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23182829/66478789-7416ea00-ea9b-11e9-8324-593f335ca405.png)

If there is an empty line at the end, this does not happen. Is it expected to just add a new line to the end of the document?

MWE [here](https://github.com/lucyleeow/Sphinx-Gallery-MWE).

items.title: ENH Add CSS for pandas dataframe
items.body:
With #541, Sphinx-Gallery can capture raw HTML (using the `_repr_html_()` of an object) and embed in rst. In some cases, where the captured raw HTML does not include CSS (e.g. pandas dataframes), this can be added to make the output look better. For reference [this](https://1052-25860190-gh.circle-artifacts.com/0/rtd_html/auto_examples/plot_capture_repr.html) (scroll down) is what a pandas dataframe looks like with just the raw HTML.

For example, Jupyter notebook seems to take CSS from their own [`renderedhtml.less`](https://github.com/jupyter/notebook/blob/master/notebook/static/notebook/less/renderedhtml.less) (see @larsoner's [post](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/541#issuecomment-539196065)). For reference this [SO](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49324569/replicating-jupyter-notebook-pandas-dataframe-html-printout) question describes how to get pandas dataframes to look like those in Jupyter notebook. 

One solution is that we can include our own CSS for common objects like pandas dataframes (I think this might be beyond the scope of SG).

~Another solution is to obtain CSS from the objects we capture `_repr_html_` from, if possible.~

Another solution would be to add a  `add_css` configuration to allow the user add their own CSS file (e.g. pandas dataframes have specific HTML tags that can be used to write CSS specifically for dataframes), a reference to which would be added at the end of raw HTML embedded.

items.title: ENH capture 'repr's of last expression
items.body:
Relates to #396 (pretty html rendering) which can be implemented in 2 steps:

1. (this issue) `eval()` last line if it is an expression. This removes the need to use `print()` to output the value of expressions.
2. Capture html output if there is a `__repr_html__`. This allows nice rendering of e.g. pandas dataframes, plots and reports (currently implemented via a 'image' scraper in [nilearn](https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/pull/2019), [nistats](https://github.com/nistats/nistats/pull/387), [mne](https://github.com/mne-tools/mne-python/pull/6433))

There has been discussion at #421 (and a WIP PR #422) about using nbconvert to execute code blocks, which would address both issues above, however there were concerns about adding dependencies and no work around was agreed upon.

The plan for this issue would be to implement the same ['exec/eval' logic ](https://github.com/jupyter/jupyter-sphinx/blob/b1d5a4568fc697e8ffb07d669432592e5f0f3aa0/jupyter_sphinx/embed_widgets.py#L65) from jupyter-sphinx (as suggested by @maartenbreddels) in [`execute_code_block()`](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/blob/master//sphinx_gallery/gen_rst.py#L456:5). Thoughts welcome.

(cc @GaelVaroquaux)

items.title: No way to prevent insertion of inlined SVG images, and instead insert raw HTML
items.body:
Sphinx-Gallery version used: 
 - 0.4.0
- latest version compatible with Python 3.6

We are working on [GLM Reporter](https://github.com/nistats/nistats/pull/352) . The feature takes some args and generates a report, which contains many inlined SVG images. The entire report is a string, including the code for the generated SVG images. 

This string is wrapped as HTMLDocument object ([nilearn.plotting.js_plotting_utils.HTMLDocument](https://github.com/nilearn/nilearn/blob/bfbc2632f90e7e8e3ee3b7036d4fd08d8ec91fec/nilearn/plotting/js_plotting_utils.py#L89)).

When we run `make html` on this, the GLM Reporter function is executed, and all the images created as SVG's (they are not saved to disk by the feature) are saved to disk and inserted into the HTML.

The HTML code, which we would want inserted, perhaps as an iframe, is not.

I have bundled the 4 files I think are pertinent to demonstrate what I am saying and maybe help reproduce & troubleshoot. This includes the `.py` source, the `.rst` and `.html` generated by Sphinx-gallery, as well the report this PR creates, containing the HTML we would like inserted into the gallery example.

The source `.py` file for the example is also at https://github.com/nistats/nistats/blob/43ebb718619a0e5021d7faa3a12c090cc5f7177e/examples/02_first_level_models/plot_adhd_dmn.py

The section I speak of is right at the bottom of the page.

Is there anyway to do one or the things we want without editing the raw html generated? 

Attached:

[example-files.zip](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/files/3529282/example-files.zip)

items.title: Small regression in 0.4.1: print(__doc__) creates empty output block
items.body:
Seen in https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/14507#issuecomment-516466110, `print(__doc__)` creates empty output box (yellowish box in the output below). 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1680079/62141734-5f74e380-b2ed-11e9-9796-4ff96ae33d63.png)

This was introduced by https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/475. A simple fix would be to not have an output box if `my_stdout.isspace()` and add a test similar to the one introduced in #475 to check that `print(__doc__)` does not create an output box.

Small reminder: many scikit-learn examples have `print(__doc__)` at the beginning, so inside sphinx-gallery we set `__doc__ = ''` (`__doc__` is already rendered at the top of the example HTML so you don't want it captured in stdout as well).

ping @lucyleeow who is interested to work on this.

items.title: Allow .rst extension for README files
items.body:
https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/blob/cd6eaed237b00ed505b3faa095694c2d66afe49d/sphinx_gallery/gen_gallery.py#L272

Currently, SG forces the required README files to have the `.txt` extension. I imagine almost every project using SG is formatting these README files in RST so allowing an `.rst` extension makes sense.

Why does this matter? It makes viewing the example directory on GitHub a bit more user-friendly as GitHub will render RST properly when the file has an `.rst` extension. See this page for example: https://github.com/pyvista/pyvista/tree/master/examples

A newcomer to the project might explore the example directory in the repo before heading to the gallery on the docs and I'd much rather have a rendered page there than unwelcoming, raw RST

items.title: Adding a ReST block immediately after the module docstring breaks the generated .rst file
items.body:
## Bug

It appears that both module docstring and ReST blocks are stripped of blank lines at the beginning and end.

Thus the example from https://sphinx-gallery.github.io/syntax.html

~~~
"""
This is my example script
=========================

This example doesn't do much, it just makes a simple plot
"""

###############################################################################
# This is a section header
# ------------------------
~~~

would result in an .rst file with
~~~
This example doesn't do much, it just makes a simple plot
This is a section header
------------------------
~~~

resulting in incorrect rendering of the section due to a missing line before it. A similar effect happens if you have just plain text paragraphs: They will be joined.

This appears to be a common pitfall:
https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/13911
https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/pull/13950

## Proposed fix

Probably the correct fix would be to always add a blank line after the module docstring text in the generated .rst file.

items.title: Small regression in 0.3.1 with output figure numbering
items.body:
There is a change of figure numbering. Before it was based on the matplotlib figure number now it is 1,2, ..., `number_of_figures`.

This is a small change that was spotted in scikit-learn doc (https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/13513), because:
- in the example .py file, we use `plt.figure(0)`
- in the rst we include the figure with `.. figure:: ../auto_examples/gaussian_process/images/sphx_glr_plot_gpc_000.png`

This can be fixed easily inside scikit-learn and I am not sure whether sphinx-gallery should do something about it. It is kind of a edge case that is not that likely to happen in practice. Maybe this could be documented it in CHANGES.rst?

Here is an example to reproduce the problem:

`examples/plot_exp_test.py:` (it is just `examples/plot_exp.py` with explicit matplotlib figure numbers)

```py
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
"""
Plotting the exponential function
=================================

A simple example for ploting two figures of a exponential
function in order to test the autonomy of the gallery
stacking multiple images.
"""

# Code source: Óscar Nájera
# License: BSD 3 clause

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


def main():
    x = np.linspace(-1, 2, 100)
    y = np.exp(x)

    plt.figure(0)
    plt.plot(x, y)
    plt.xlabel('$x$')
    plt.ylabel('$\exp(x)$')

    plt.figure(4)
    plt.plot(x, -np.exp(-x))
    plt.xlabel('$x$')
    plt.ylabel('$-\exp(-x)$')

    plt.show()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

```
cd doc
make clean html
ls -1 auto_examples/images/sphx_glr_plot_exp_test_*
```

Output on 0.2.0:
```
auto_examples/images/sphx_glr_plot_exp_test_000.png
auto_examples/images/sphx_glr_plot_exp_test_004.png
```

Output on 0.3.1:
```
auto_examples/images/sphx_glr_plot_exp_test_001.png
auto_examples/images/sphx_glr_plot_exp_test_002.png
```

items.title: SG not respecting highlight_lang in conf.py
items.body:
If I specify `highlight_language = 'python3'` in my `conf.py`, sphinx-gallery nonetheless outputs code blocks starting with:
```
.. code-block:: python
```
...presumably because of [default `lang=python` arg in `codestr2rst`](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/blob/40aec52de43e4c27b000e054ae50eae6fb0f30e2/sphinx_gallery/gen_rst.py#L178).  This leads to errors where plain RST files get lexed as python3, but the gallery files get lexed as python2 (which chokes on the `@` operator), as evidenced by these two errors:
```
/opt/mne-python/doc/auto_tutorials/preprocessing/working_with_projectors.rst:48: WARNING: Could not lex literal_block as "python". Highlighting skipped.
/opt/mne-python/doc/manual/gui/browse.rst:2533: WARNING: Could not lex literal_block as "python3". Highlighting skipped.
```
(note: the second is an intentional error that I left in manual/gui/browse.rst to demonstrate that it is being lexed as py3, unlike the SG-generated rst files)

items.title: sphinx-gallery doesn't play nice with sphinx's ability to detect new files...
items.body:
As pointed out by @larsoner (https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/448#issuecomment-467608061_):

I think I have narrowed it down to these to `conf.py` entries:
```
    'subsection_order': gallery_order.sectionorder,
    'within_subsection_order': gallery_order.subsectionorder,
```
I'm guessing that it's because Sphinx can't tell if these config values have changed or not, so decides to re-write everything. With those two lines as they are in `mpl` master:

... what we could do is allow these entries to be strings and do some `importlib` magic with them, rather than allowing them to be classes directly. That *should* allow `sphinx` to treat them as static, rather than unknowns. In this case making changes to your classes will not be reflected in the build, but this should be (much) rarer than the case of changing a single example, and also can be worked around with a simple `make clean` (or removing the quotes from the name) when you want to do this.

_Originally posted by @larsoner in https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/pull/448#issuecomment-467608061_

items.title: sub-galleries should be generated with a separate "gallery rst" file
items.body:
One of the challenges with sphinx-gallery is that it doesn't give a lot of flexibility with how you slice and dice the gallery. Since we don't allow for things like directives, you can't say "show the example gallery for these python files here, and those python files there" super easily. One way to get around this would be to build all of the gallery code for sub-galleries (e.g. those within sub-folders of the main gallery folder) as separate text files, and then **include** them in the built gallery (minus the label). This would let users add the sub-galleries in other places if they so-wished. ## An example For example, in the SG repo, we have the `sin_func` sub-folder in [the examples folder](https://github.com/sphinx-gallery/sphinx-gallery/tree/master/examples). When the gallery is built, the gallery for the `sin_func` folder is placed within `index.rst` in a block like this: ``` ...other gallery code... .. _sin_examples: The sin function ---------------- Specific examples for the sin function. Saved in the examples directory in a subfolder. .. raw:: html
.. only:: html .. figure:: /auto_examples/sin_func/images/thumb/sphx_glr_plot_sin_thumb.png :ref:`sphx_glr_auto_examples_sin_func_plot_sin.py` .. raw:: html
.. toctree:: :hidden: /auto_examples/sin_func/plot_sin .. raw:: html
...rest of gallery code... ``` This means that the rST for the `sin_func` gallery is interwoven with the gallery for the entire `examples` folder. What if the user wanted to highlight only the `sin_func` folder in a location in their docs? If instead we put the `sin_func` rST in a separate folder (e.g. in `sin_func/index.txt`) and then included it in the main `index.rst` file like so: ``` ...other gallery code... .. _sin_examples: .. include:: sin_func/index.txt ...rest of gallery code... ``` then people could choose to include the `sin_func` mini-gallery wherever they like. Does that make sense? I think it'd be a relatively simple patch since these are all auto-generated. What do folks think?

items.title: Sprint tomorrow @ euroscipy?
items.body:
Hi devs,

I am considering doing a sprint on sphinx-gallery tomorrow at euroscipy, partly to onboard new devs, partly to work on features / merging. WDYT?
